text.title: part8_US presidential candidate Duncan Hunter speaks to Wikinews
text.head: Gay Marriage

p.hi: Do you consider yourself States Rights ?

text.p:
DH :
I think so . I think that 's a general philosophy . Federalism . I do n't think it 's absolute ; I think there are some issues in which the country as a nation has an interest .

p.hi: Why would you support the Federal Marriage Amendment if you are for States Rights ?

text.p:
DH :
Because of what I just told you . I think that states rights are important , but there are some issues in which the nation as a community has an interest , and of course the Marriage Act , one of the fears has been if you end up with one or two states that support homosexual marriage , what you 'll end up doing is producing a flow of people going to a particular state , receiving their marriage license in that state , and then due to the Full Faith and Credit Clause of the Constitution , having those marriages recognized in the state where the marriage is banned .

p.hi: Does n't DOMA prevent that ? The Defense of Marriage Act ?

text.p:
DH :
Well , if you end up with a federal act that prohibits it -- that 's what I 'm saying , if you prohibit it on a national basis in a Constitutional Amendment or on a federal act , then you eliminate the process of having one or two states generating homosexual marriages and then demanding they be recognized under the Full Faith and Credit Clause . Do you understand what I 'm saying ? If you have one state that allows it , then you have a recognition requirement of the other states .

p.hi: But did n't DOMA prevent that ? Massachusetts currently has gay marriage . So did n't DOMA prevent that from happening ?
Prevent a swell of people going to Massachusetts and getting married , and then taking their marriage to another state that bans it and forcing them to recognize it ?

text.p:
DH :
What 's your point ? I think that 's good . That it does prevent it .

p.hi: So do you no longer support amending the Constitution is my question .

text.p:
DH :
No , I think it has still yet to be fully decided as to whether a few states can at some point basically become proliferators , if you will , of non-traditional marriage . Here 's my position : If it is necessary to amend the Constitution , then I think we will need to do it . I think you need to have a Defense of Marriage on a uniform basis in all fifty states . What it takes , in terms of satsifying the federal courts to do that , should be done . So if it is required that it is necessary to have an amendment to the Constitution to do that , I would support that . But doing what it takes to have a uniform treatment to defend traditional marriage across all the states .
